column1: Cuban Americans (Spanish: cubanoestadounidenses or Spanish: cubanoamericanos) are Americans who trace their ancestry to Cuba. The word may refer to someone born in the U.S. of Cuban descent or to someone who has emigrated to the U.S. from Cuba. Cuban Americans are the third largest Hispanic American group in the United States.
Many communities throughout the United States have significant Cuban American populations. Florida (1.53 million in 2017) has the highest concentration of Cuban Americans in the U.S.

column1: After the Cuban revolution led by Fidel Castro in 1959
column2: a Cuban exodus began as the new government allied itself with the Soviet Union and began to introduce communism. The first Cubans to come to America after the revolution were those affiliated with former dictator Fulgencio Batista
column3: next were Cuba's professionals. Most Cuban Americans that arrived in the United States initially came from Cuba's educated upper and middle classes centered in Cuba's capital Havana. This middle class arose in the period after the Platt Amendment when Cuba became one of the most successful countries in Latin America. Between December 1960 and October 1962 more than 14
column4: 000 Cuban children arrived alone in the U.S. Their parents were afraid that their children were going to be sent to some Soviet bloc countries to be educated and they decided to send them to the States as soon as possible.This program was called Operation Peter Pan (Operacion Pedro Pan). When the children arrived in Miami they were met by representatives of Catholic Charities and they were sent to live with relatives if they had any or were sent to foster homes

column2: after the implementation of the "Wet feet
column3: dry feet" policy immigration patterns changed. Many Cuban immigrants departed from the southern and western coasts of Cuba and arrived at the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico; many landed on Isla Mujeres. From there Cuban immigrants traveled to the Texas-Mexico border and found asylum. Many of the Cubans who did not have family in Miami settled in Houston; this has caused Houston's Cuban-American community to increase in size. The term "dusty foot" refers to Cubans emigrating to the U.S. through Mexico. In 2005 the Department of Homeland Security had abandoned the approach of detaining every dry foot Cuban who crosses through Texas and began a policy allowing most Cubans to obtain immediate parole.Jorge Ferragut
column4: a Cuban immigrant who founded Casa Cuba

column6: said in a 2008 article that many Cuban immigrants of the first decade of the 21st century left due to economic instead of political issues. By October 2008 Mexico and Cuba created an agreement to prevent immigration of Cubans through Mexico.In recent years

column8: Puerto Rico is seen as a stepping stone for Cubans trying to get to the continental U.S.
column9: though Puerto Rico itself is home to a number of Cubans.

column1: The ancestry of Cuban Americans is primarily from Spaniards and Black Africans
column2: as well as more distant ancestry from among the indigenous peoples of the Caribbean and those of Florida. During the 18th

column5: Basques
column6: Canarians
column7: Catalans
column8: Andalusians
column9: Asturians and Galicians). Canarians immigrated to many countries along the Caribbean from Louisiana to Venezuela. But Cuba was the Latin American culture most influenced by the emigration of Canary Islanders (they developed the production of sugar in Cuba)
column10: and Cuban Spanish is closest to that of the Canary Islands. Canary Islanders were viewed by other Spanish-Cubans as superstitious but also hard-working. Some of Haiti's white population (French) migrated to Cuba after the Haitian War of Independence in the early 18th century.  Also
column11: minor but significant ethnic influx is derived from diverse peoples from Middle East places such as Lebanon and Palestine.

column1: Cuban Americans are mostly Roman Catholic
column2: but some Cubans practice African traditional religions (such as Santería or Ifá)
column3: which evolved from mixing the Catholic religion with the traditional African religion. Cuban Catholicism was also influenced by the Catholicism practiced by the Canarian people. However
column4: there are many Protestant (primarily Pentecostal) with small numbers of syncretist
column5: nonreligious or tiny communities of Jewish and Muslim Cuban Americans. The Protestant movement in Cuba started after the Spanish–American War when many Americans came to Cuba.

column2: Cuban Americans historically tended to be more Republican than Democratic
column3: thanks to the anti-communist foreign policy platform of the Republican Party since the 1950s. The failed Bay of Pigs invasion left many Cubans distrustful of the Democratic Party
column4: blaming John F. Kennedy for his handling of the 1961 Bay of Pigs Invasion. Cuban exiles began an alliance with the Republican Party of Florida. In Florida
column5: Cuban-American congressmen have tended to be Republican
column6: beginning with Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (Joe Garcia
column7: a Democrat
column8: is an exception). The presence of Cubans in the Republican Party was highlighted by the 2016 presidential race
column9: which featured U.S. Senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio as prominent candidates
column10: both of whom are of Cuban descent. But in New Jersey
column11: another state with many Cuban Americans
column12: Cuban-American congressmen have tended to be Democrats
column13: for example Representative Albio Sires and Senator Bob Menendez. Ronald Reagan is particularly popular in the Cuban-American community for standing up to Soviet communism and Fidel Castro's so-called "exportation of revolution" to Central America and Africa (there is a street in Miami named for Reagan)
column14: and George W. Bush received 75 and 78 percent (in 2000 and 2004 respectively) of the Cuban-American vote. The Cuban-American lobby has also lobbied both parties on causes important to Cuban Americans.

column2: the Cuban-American vote has become more contested between the parties. In the 2008 United States presidential election
column3: Democrat Barack Obama received 47% of the Cuban-American vote in Florida. According to Bendixen's exit polls
column4: 84% of Miami-Dade Cuban-American voters 65 or older backed John McCain
column5: while 55% of those 29 or younger backed Obama. In 2012
column6: Barack Obama received 49 percent of the Cuban-American vote in Florida
column7: compared to 47 percent for Mitt Romney according to Edison Research exits polls. By spring 2014
column8: this trend increased among Cuban American voters having a preference for Democratic Party candidates increased particularly for younger voters aged 18–49
column9: increasing to some 56% for the younger voter demographic
column10: versus Cuban-American voters over 50 years of age having a 39% preference for Democratic candidates. As in the 2012 United States presidential election
column11: Mitt Romney got more support than Barack Obama. The 2016 United States presidential election saw Donald Trump garner about the same level support within the community
column12: garnering 50–54 percent of the Floridian Cuban-American vote
column13: as opposed to 41–48 percent for Hillary Clinton
column14: as some Cuban Americans were dissatisfied with Obama's Cuba policy
column15: which restored foreign relations with the Cuban government.
